abstract.p: Bob Goree letter compares business travel to destinations outside center cities, using train, plane or automobile (S)

block.p: To the Editor: The article missed a major point in the comparison. Increasingly, business offices are not in city centers but in outer suburbs. When you factor in a trip by taxi, limo or rented car from the arrival point to an outer suburb, travel around the city from airport to office beats travel from city center to outer suburban office. This is true even in Europe, where train travel is far faster and likely to stay that way, given relative levels of investment. Only bad flying weather levels the playing field.

To the Editor: The article missed a major point in the comparison. Increasingly, business offices are not in city centers but in outer suburbs. When you factor in a trip by taxi, limo or rented car from the arrival point to an outer suburb, travel around the city from airport to office beats travel from city center to outer suburban office. This is true even in Europe, where train travel is far faster and likely to stay that way, given relative levels of investment. Only bad flying weather levels the playing field.

Trains are a fine way of traveling under 100 miles, or between city centers up to 300 miles or so distant, and for leisure. For most business travel in the United States that does not fit into this tight category, planes and road travel offer far more convenience and flexibility. When you factor in the infrastructure cost for state-of-the-art train travel, it is hard to imagine why the American public should ever support it.
